emphasis.docTitle:
A note on the author citation and typification of
Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe
(
Tephroseris integrifolia subsp. aurantiaca
; Asteraceae )

subSection.paragraph: FABRIZIO BARTOLUCCI 1,4, *, MARIACRISTINA VILLANI 2,5 & GABRIELE GALASSO 3,6

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Scuola di Bioscienze e Medicina Veterinaria, Università di Camerino–Centro Ricerche Floristiche dell’Appennino, Parco Nazionale del Gran Sasso e Monti della Laga, San Colombo, I–67021 Barisciano (L’Aquila), Italy .
Centro di ateneo Orto Botanico, Università di Padova, via Orto Botanico 15, 35123 Padova, Italy .
Sezione di Botanica, Museo di Storia Naturale di Milano, Corso Venezia 55, 20121 Milano, Italy .

subSection.paragraph:
The genus
Tephroseris
(Rchb. in Mössler 1829: 1498 ) Reichenbach (1841: 87) comprises 15 ( Cufodontis 1933 ) to about 50 ( Nordenstam 2007 ) species distributed in Europe, Asia, and North America.
Tephroseris integrifolia ( Linnaeus 1753: 925 ) Holub (1973: 173) subsp. aurantiaca
“(Hoppe ex Willdenow 1803: 2081) Nordenstam (1978: 44) ” is a name currently accepted for a subspecies native to Austria , Czech Republic , Germany , Hungary , Poland , Switzerland , Ukraine , and Balkan Peninsula ( Greuter 2006 +, CWG 2021, POWO 2021 , WFO 2021 ). In Italy it was recorded by mistake (Bartolucci et al. 2018, 2020).

The intended new combination “
Tephroseris integrifolia subsp. aurantiaca
” was proposed by Nordenstam (1978) with a full and direct reference to “
Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe ex Willd., Sp. Pl.
, ed. 4 [Willdenow] 3(3): 2081. 1803”. However,
Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe ex Willd.
is a later isonym (Art. 6 Note 2; Turland et al. 2018 , hereafter ICN) or, more correctly, a re-use of
Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe (1803)
, which was described and therefore validly published on the printed herbarium label (Art. 30.8 and Ex. 12 of the ICN) of the fourth century of Hoppe’s exsiccata “ Herbarium vivum plantarum rariorum praesertim alpinarum ”. According to Dalla Torre & Sarnthein (1900) , the fourth century of this series was distributed in 1803, while the list of the species included in it was published in 1804 ( Hoppe 1804 ). Because Willdenow (1803) provided an explicit reference to Hoppe’s series of exsiccata as “
C. ( aurantiaca ) foliis radicalibus ovatis petiolatis subdentatis, caulinis linearibus integerrimis decurrentibus, caule paucifloro. Hoppe cent. Pl. 4
”, it can be deduced that the herbarium samples of the series with Hoppe’s description of
C. aurantiaca
were with certainty distributed, and therefore effectively published, before Willdenow’s description. Due to the presence of an explicit reference to the place of original publication in Willdenow’s work, Art. 41.8(a) of the ICN does not apply and the combination under
Tephroseris integrifolia
was not validly published by Nordenstam (1978) .

See also Hämet-Ahti (1971) and Verloove & Galasso (2020) for similar cases, concerning the typification of a Hoppe’s species name published in the above cited centuries of exsiccata (
Juncus glabratus Hoppe 1800
: s.n.), or a species name published on a printed label of commercially distributed specimens (
Sida bidentata Hochstetter 1842
: No. 1003), respectively. The typification of the name
Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe
and the correct author citation for
Tephroseris integrifolia subsp. aurantiaca
are provided below.

Tephroseris integrifolia subsp. aurantiaca (Hoppe) B.Nord. ex Greuter
in Greuter & Raab-Straube (2008: 778) ; Nordenstam (1978: 44) , comb. inval. ≡
Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe (1803
: s.n.) ≡
Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe ex Willd. (1803: 2081)
, isonym.

Type ( lectotype , designated here): AUSTRIA . Habitat in Carinthiae pratis. / Exemplaria die 10 Iun. prope Klagenfurtum legi, Hoppe s.n. (B barcode B-W16008-010; isolectotypes: BP No. 466549, MW barcode MW0595116, U No. U. 1137399, W-Rchb. No. 1889- 0029807; image of the lectotype is available at https://herbarium.bgbm.org/object/BW16008010, image ID: 391978)
.

Nomencaltural note :—The conditions for valid publication of the name “
Tephroseris integrifolia subsp. aurantiaca
” were unintentionally fulfilled by Greuter in Greuter & Raab-Straube (2008: 778) , who accepted the name and cited all relevant combinations based on “
Cineraria aurantiaca Willd.
” with the addition of a full and direct reference to the protologue of a heterotypic synonym,
Senecio besserianus Minderova (1956: 58)
. Without the effect of Art. 41.8(c), the combination
Tephroseris integrifolia subsp. aurantiaca
would have been a replacement name at a new rank for
Senecio besserianus
. With the effect of this provision, it was validly published as a new combination based on
Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe (1803)
, in order to avoid the disadvantageous nomenclatural consequences of erroneous citations. The previous (involuntary) online combination by Greuter (2006 +) is not validly published as electronic material may be only effectively distributed on or after 1 January 2012 and only via Portable Document Format (PDF) (Art. 29.1 of the ICN).

Typification note :—We traced some relevant duplicate specimens belonging to the original material of the name
Cineraria aurantiaca
at B, BP, MW, U, and W (codes according to Thiers 2021 ). The herbarium specimen kept in the Wildenow’s herbarium at B, with the printed label of the Hoppe’s series of exsiccata ( Hoppe 1803 ) and a second label in Hoppe’s handwriting “
Cineraria aurantiaca mihi . nach Jacquin varietas Ciner alpinae! (Hoppe)
”, is selected here as the lectotype .
We thank Alexander Sennikov for valuable comments that improved the first version of the manuscript.

Bartolucci, F., Domina, G., Bagella, S., Barberis, G., Briozzo, I., Calbi, M., Caria, M.C., Cavallaro, V., Chianese, G., Cibei, C., Conti, F., Dagnino, D., Esposito, A., Galasso, G., Giacanelli, V., Forte, L., Gottschlich, G., Lattanzi, E., Longo, D., Mei, G., Merli, M., Orsenigo, S., Pau, G.B., Pazienza, G., Peccenini, S., Pisanu, S., Rivieccio, G., Roma-Marzio, F., Scafidi, F., Selvi, F., Stinca, A., Turcato, C. & Nepi, C. (2020) Notulae to the Italian native vascular flora: 10. Italian Botanist 10: 47–55.
